awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Toward Enforceable Data Usage Control in Cloud-based IoT Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
In the upcoming evolution of the Internet of Things (IoT), it is anticipated that billions of devices will be connected to the Internet. While IoT promises a more connected and smarter world, this pervasive large-scale data collection, storage, sharing, and analysis raise many privacy concerns. In the current IoT ecosystem, IoT service providers have full control of the collected user data. They use the data for smart IoT system and device control. They could also use the data for other purposes not consented to by the users. This project proposes a novel data usage control framework, PrivacyGuard, that aims to empower data owners with full control over how their sensitive data is used so as to protect the data from certain types of privacy breaches. PrivacyGuard ensures that user data can only be used only by user-approved programs and each use of data has a non-repudiable usage record. Students from underrepresented minority groups will be involved in the research activities.

The proposed PrivacyGuard framework aims to achieve this goal by seamlessly integrating two new technologies, smart contract over blockchain and attested trusted execution environment (TEE). There are four key research thrusts in this project. The first thrust focuses on the design of an IoT data protection framework that coexists with the existing architecture at different layers of communication. The second research thrust aims to develop novel techniques to enable the confidential execution of contract function off-chain, by exploiting hardware-assisted TEE and its associated attestation technologies. The third thrust focuses on smart contract designs to effectively embed user-defined privacy policies and trustworthy tracking of data usage using the blockchain. The last thrusts integrates the aforementioned components to develop an open-source framework prototype.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project addresses the critical issue of data security and privacy in Internet of Things (IoT) networks, where vast amounts of data are collected, stored, shared, and analyzed by diverse entities. While data access control is essential for ensuring data security, this project advances the technology by enabling data owners to control how their data is used, an essential capability for preventing unauthorized secondary data misuse.

The primary technical innovation of this project is PrivacyGuard, a data usage control framework that seamlessly integrates two key technologies: 1) Smart contracts over blockchain to manage user-defined data usage policies, and 2) Attested trusted execution environments (TEEs) to securely execute smart contracts off-chain, achieving scalability and performance gains.

An open-source prototype system was developed and published, demonstrating the feasibility and capabilities of the proposed framework. Furthermore, the integration of smart contracts for privacy policy enforcement with other privacy-enhancing technologies has been explored and validated in additional systems, such as spectrum access systems (SAS), to protect user spectrum information privacy.

The project has resulted in the publication of over 20 research papers, and the findings, along with the developed prototypes, have been made available to the research community. These contributions provide a solid foundation for further exploration and innovation. In particular, our categorization and exploration of blockchain technology for decentralized system security and privacy, combined with the use of TEEs, offer a pathway to generalizable security solutions that enable more efficient and secure system designs. A survey paper, "A Survey of Distributed Consensus Protocols for Blockchain Networks," published in IEEE Communications Surveys & Tutorials in 2020, has garnered over 1,000 citations in just four years, shown its impact in the field.

The project also contributed to workforce development by providing partial support and training in cybersecurity and wireless networks for multiple Ph.D. students. One Ph.D. student, primarily supported by this project, successfully defended his dissertation, titled "Blockchain and Distributed Consensus: From Security Analysis to Novel Applications," and has since started an academic career as an assistant professor.
